DMBP00005154	 Mesorhizobium japonicum (ja.po′ni.cum. N.L. neut. adj. japonicum pertaining to Japan, referring to the place of isolation of the type strain).Gram-stain-negative, aerobic rods as for the other species of the genus. Colonies on YMA are white, circular and convex with a diameter of 1–2 mm within 4–5 days at 28 °C. It grows at temperatures from 15 to 34 °C and optimally at 28 °C. The pH range for growth is pH 6 to 8 with optimum growth at pH 7. It grows with up to 0.5 % NaCl on YMA medium. Nitrate reduction, arginine dihydrolase and gelatinase are negative and urease and β-galactosidase are positive. Aesculin hydrolysis is positive. Assimilation of mannose, l-rhamnose, N-acetylglucosamine, d-ribose, inositol, sucrose, maltose, mannitol, glucose, salicin, melibiose, l-fucose, d-sorbitol, l-arabinose, 4-hydroxybenzoate, gluconate, l-histidine and l-proline is positive. Assimilation of itaconate, suberate, malonate, caprate, valerate, citrate, phenylacetate, 2 ketogluconate, glycogen, 3-hydroxybenzoate, l-alanine and l-serine is negative. Propionate, 3-hydroxybutyrate, acetate, adipate, malate and d,l-lactate are weakly assimilated. Assimilation of 5-ketogluconate is variable with negative result for the type strain. Acid production from glycerol, d-arabinose, l-arabinose, d-ribose, d-xylose, l-xylose, d-adonitol, d-galactose, d-glucose, d-fructose, d-mannose, l-rhamnose, d-mannitol, d-lyxose, d-fucose and l-fucose is positive. Acid production from d-sorbitol, N-acetylglucosamine, melibiose, sucrose, trehalose and d-arabitol is weakly positive. Acid from inositol, xylitol and l-arabitol is variable with negative results for the type strain. Acid production from erythritol, methyl α-d-xyloside, l-sorbose, dulcitol, methyl α-d-mannoside, methyl α-d-glucoside, amygdalin, salicin, cellobiose, maltose, lactose, inulin, melezitose, raffinose, starch, glycogen, gentiobiose, turanose and d-tagatose is negative. Assimilation of aesculin and arbutin is positive. Alkali production from potassium gluconate, an 2- and 5-ketogluconate is negative. Sensitive to neomycin, ampicillin, gentamycin, cefuroxime, penicillin and tetracycline and resistant to cloxacillin and erythromycin. Resistance to polymyxin B and cyprofloxacin is variable with the type strain being sensitive.The type strain, MAFF 303099T (=LMG 29417T=CECT 9101T), was isolated from root nodules of Lotus japonicum in Japan. The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 62.9 mol%.10.1099/ijsem.0.001448
DMBP00005221	Dermacoccus abyssi (a.bys9si. N.L. gen. n. abyssi of an abyss).Non-acid–alcohol-fast, non-motile actinomycete. Formscoccoid cells (diameter 0?8–1?5 mm) that occur in irregularclusters. Cream to pale-yellow, circular, entire, convex,smooth, glistening colonies are formed on glucose-yeastextract agar after 5 days at 28 uC. Grows well on tryptic soyagar, but poorly on inorganic nitrogen agar. Growth occursbetween 10 and 37 uC, with optimum growth around 28 uC.Casein, cellulose, hypoxanthine, starch and uric acid aredegraded. Growth occurs in the presence of 7?5 % NaCl.Additional phenotypic properties are shown in Table 1.Grows well in glucose-yeast extract broth at 40 MPa.The type and only strain is isolate MT1.1T (=DSM17573T=NCIMB 14084T), recovered from sediment collected from the Challenger Deep of the Mariana Trench at adepth of 10 898 m. The DNA G+C content of the typestrain is 65?2 mol%.
DMBP00005222	(a.ci.di.ce'ler. N.L. neut. n. acidum an acid; from L. masc. adj. acidus sour; L. masc. adj. celer fast, N.L. masc. adj. acidiceler fast growing in acid).Basonym: Bacillus acidiceler Peak et al. 2007The description of this species is the same as provided by Peak et al. [110] for Bacillus acidiceler.Type strain: DSM 18954=NRRL B-41736=CBD 0119.Gottfriedia (Gott.frie'di.a. N.L. fem. n. Gottfriedia named after Christian Gottfried Ehrenberg (1795–1876), German Scientist and naturalist, who initially proposed the name Bacillus for rod-shaped bacteria, for his contributions on the studies of microscopic organisms).Aerobic or facultatively aerobic rods exhibiting Gram-positive or Gram-variable staining response. Form endospores and some species are motile. Observed temperature range is 15–45 °C, with optimum growth occurring in the range 30–40 °C. Members of this genus form a monophyletic clade in phylogenetic trees based on concatenated sequences for several large datasets of proteins. In addition, the members of this genus can be reliably distinguished from all other Bacillaceae species by the 14 CSIs described in Table 3 found in the following proteins: ABC transporter substrate-binding protein, helicase-exonuclease subunit AddAB subunit AddA, MFS transporter, 3-oxoacid CoA-transferase subunit B, LTA synthase family protein, sulphate ABC transporter permease subunit CysW, class I SAM-dependent RNA methyltransferase, site-specific tyrosine recombinase XerD, 3-isopropylmalate dehydrogenase, 5-oxoprolinase subunit PxpB, MATE family efflux transporter, ABC transporter permease, MBL fold metallo-hydrolase and YitT family protein, which in most cases are exclusively shared by either all or most members of this genus. The type species is Gottfriedia luciferensis.10.1099/ijsem.0.004475
DMBP00005243	S. pratensis (pra.ten’sis.L. fem. adj. pratensis growing in a meadow, referring to the isolation of strains from grassland). The description is based on data taken from this and previous studies [9,19]. The organisms form extensively branched substrate hyphae, and aerialhyphae that carry smooth-surfaced spores inrectiflexibiles spore chains. Abundant off-white to greenish gray aerial spore mass is formed in a yellow to yellowish brown substrate mycelium on ISP media 2, 3, 4 and 5. Growth occurs at pH 6.0–11.0, but not at pH 5.0. Growth occurs between 15 and 37 ◦C, but not at 4 or 45 ◦C, and in the presence of 5% NaCl (w/v), but not in the presence of 15% NaCl (w/v). Nitrate is reduced. Strains are positive for cellulose, milk, Tween 20, Tween 60 and Tween 80 degradation, but negative for aesculin, arbutin, chitosan, guanine, urease and xanthine degradation. The hydrolysis of gelatin is variable. Strains are positive for assimilation of l-arabinose, d-cellobiose, d-fructose, d-fucose, d-glucose, maltose, mannitol, d-mannose, draffinose, l-rhamnose, d-ribose and d-xylose, weakly positive for lactose, but negative for assimilation of sodium acetate, d-sucrose and trisodium citrate dihydrate. The cell wall is type I,the phospholipid type II and the predominant menaquinone is MK-9 (H6, H8). The major fatty acids (>10%) are anteiso-C15:0, iso-C16:0 and C16:0. The G + C content of the DNA is 70.0–71.0 mol%. The type strain is ch24T (=CGMCC 4.6829T = NRRL B-24916T), and was isolated from grassy field soil in Charlotte, NC, USA.

DMBP00005443	 Streptomyces roseifaciens (ro.se.i.fa′ci.ens L. masc. adj. roseus rosy; L. pres. part. faciens producing; N.L. part. adj. roseifaciens producing rosy colour).Aerobic, Gram-stain positive actinobacterium which forms an extensively branched substrate mycelium that carries long straight filaments bearing at more or less regular intervals branches arranged in verticils. Each branch of the verticils produces at its apex short chains of three to five spores with smooth surfaces. Grows well on all ISP media. A red substrate mycelium, a pink aerial spore mass and a pale brown diffusible pigment are produced on oatmeal agar. Grows from 20 to 50 ˚C, optimally at ~30 ˚C, from pH 5.0 to pH 11, optimally at pH~7, and in the presence of 2 % NaCl. Produces acid and alkaline phosphatase, α-chymotrypsin, α-cysteine arylamidase, esterase (C4), esterase lipase (C8), N-acetyl-β-glucosaminidase, α- and β-glucosidase, α-mannosidase, naphthol-AS-B1-phosphatase, trypsin and valine arylamidase, but not α-fucosidase, α- or β-galactosidase, or β-glucoronidase (API-ZYM tests). Degrades casein, gelatin, hypoxanthine, starch and l-tyrosine. Glucose, inositol and sucrose are used as sole carbon sources. Additional phenotype properties are given in Tables 1 and 2. Major fatty acids are anteiso-C15 : 0, and anteiso-C17 : 0, the predominant menaquinone is MK-9(H8), the polar lipid profile contains diphospatidylglycerol, phosphatidylethanolamine, phosphatidylinositol, glycophospholipid and an unidentified lipid, the DNA G+C composition is 71.9 mol% and the genome size is 8.64 Mbp. The genome contains 44 biosynthetic gene clusters, many of which encode for unknown specialized metabolites.The type strain, MBT76T (=NCCB 100637T=DSM 106196T), was isolated from a soil sample from the QinLing mountains, Shaanxi Province, China. The species description is based on a single strain and hence serves as a description of the type strain. The GenBank accession number for the assembled genome of Streptomyces roseifaciens is GCA_001445655.1.
DMBP00005608	Streptomyces thinghirensis (thin.ghi.ren′sis. N.L. masc. adj. thinghirensis of Thinghir, named after the town in Southern Morocco where the strain was isolated).Hyphae are abundant and well-developed. A yellow diffusible pigment is produced on all test media and yellow substrate mycelium and white–grey aerial mycelium are visible. No melanin production is observed on peptone-yeast extract-iron agar (ISP 6) or tyrosine agar (ISP 7). Good growth is observed on ISP 2 agar. Gelatin is not liquefied. Milk is coagulated and peptonized. H2S is not produced. Nitrate is reduced. d-Fructose, d-galactose, d-glucose, d-mannitol, d-mannose, myo-inositol, l-rhamnose and d-sorbitol are utilized as sole carbon sources. d-Sucrose, maltose, d-lactose and cellobiose are weakly utilized, while d-arabinose, d-xylose and raffinose are not utilized as sole carbon sources. Growth occurs from 28 to 42 °C, from pH 5 to pH 10, and in the presence of 7 % (w/v) NaCl. Resistant to (μg ml−1): ampicillin (10), amoxicillin (10), nalidixic acid (30), penicillin G (10), sulfamide (25) and rifampicin (5), but sensitive to novobiocin (30), gentamicin (10) and streptomycin (10). Active against the moulds Aspergillus niger, Fusarium oxysporum f. sp. albedinis, Pythium ultimum, Sclerotium rolfsii and Verticillium dahliae, the yeasts Candida albicans, Candida tropicalis and Saccharomyces cerevisiae, and the bacteria Bacillus subtilis, Bacillus cereus, Escherichia coli and Streptomyces scabiei.The type strain, S10T (=CCMM B35T=DSM 41919T), was isolated from the rhizosphere soil of wild Vitis vinifera plants.
DMBP00005611	Streptomyces tritolerans (tri’to.le.rans.L.pref. triple. three. L. pres. part. tolerans. tolerating; N.L. part. adj. tritolerans referring to the ability of the organism to tolerate high salinity, alkalinity and temperature). The strain is Gram-positive, non motile, alkalitolerant and thermotolerant with good growth without fragmentation. Aerial mycelium is white to gray. Diffusible pigments are not formed. Spores are smooth, 0.6–1.0 µm in diameter arranged in straight to flexous chains of 10–15 spores. Arabinose, fructose, galactose, glucose, D-mannitol, rhamnose, raffinose, sucrose and xylose are utilized as sole carbon and energy sources but not inositol. Acid is not formed from these carbon sources. L-asparagine, L-alanine, L-cysteine (weak), L-histidine and L-phenylalanine are used as sole nitrogen sources, but not L-arginine. Starch, casein and cellulose are hydrolyzed. Urea is not hydrolyzed. Nitrate reduction and H2S production are negative. Tests for gelatin hydrolysis and melanin production are positive. Growth occurs from 28 to 45C, pH 7–10, and in presence of sodium chloride (7% w/v). Resistance to novobiocin, ampicillin, amoxycillin, nalidixic acid, penicillin G, norfloxacin, rifampicin and carbencillin but sensitive to ciprofloxacin, gentamicin, neomycin, erythromycin, streptomycin, tetracycline, chloramphenicol and vancomycin. The cell wall of strain DAS 165T contains LL-DAP, but no diagnostic sugars. MK-9 (H6)-78% is the major menaquinone and minor amount of MK-9 (H4)-8% and MK-9(H8)-14% are also present. The diagnostic phospholipid is phosphatidylethanolamine. The major cellular fatty acids are isoC15:0(14%), anteisoC15:0(18%), C16:0(10%) and isoC16:0(28%). The G + C content of the genomic DNA is 69.7 mol%. The strain DAS 165T was isolated from alkaline soil in Gulbarga, Karnataka province, India
DMBP00005669	Bacdive
DMBP00005683	Ther.mo.line.a'ta. Gr. f. n. thermi? heat; L. adj. lineatus, of a line, rectilinear. L. f. n. thermolineata heat(-loving), linear (referring to spore chains). Good growth at 40 ◦C on V-8 juice agar, producing abundant aerial mycelium in the green colour series, 24 ih to 24i ih. Colony reverse yellow-brown with no distinctive pigments. No melanoid pigment produced on peptone iron agar. Spores in straight or flexuous chains less than 30 spores long (Fig. 5a). Spores smooth but ends often prolonged, projecting from the oval spore body and retaining their shape under vacuum when the rest of the spore collapses, to give a phalangiform appearance (Fig. 5b; Tresner et al., 1966). Spores measure 1.0-2.1 x 0.9-1.3 µm, mean 1.43 x 1.06 µm. Degrades casein, gelatin and starch, uses trehalose and sometimes cellobiose and mannitol as sole carbon sources, and L-arginine, L-histidine, L-hydroxyproline, L-methionine, L-phenylalanine, potassium nitrate, L-serine and L-valine as sole nitrogen sources. Reduces nitrate to nitrite and sometimes shows lipolytic and proteolytic activity on egg yolk. Isolated from sewage compost. Type culture: DSM 41451 = K47 = A1484.

N.L. masc. adj. arilaitensis of Arilait, arbitraryname formed to honor Arilait-Recherches, a research association that coordinates the collective research programs of theprofessional French dairy federations.The description was based on the study of nine strains.Cells are aerobic, Gram-stain-positive, catalase-positive,oxidase-negative, non-spore-forming, nonmotile, and exhibita rod–coccus growth cycle. Colonies on Brain Heart Infu-sion agar are yellow, round, smooth, convex, and 2 mmin diameter. Grows between 10 and 30∘C and toleratesup to 10% (w/v) NaCl. Gelatinase, β-galactosidase, pyrazinamidase, pyrrolidonyl arylamidase, phosphatase, andα-glucosidase are produced. Urease and esculin are nothydrolyzed. Nitrate is not reduced. Glucose, ribose, xylose,mannitol, maltose, lactose, sucrose, and glycogen are notfermented. The typestrain Re117 utilizes the following substrates as sole carbonsources: D-glucose, D-galactose, D-trehalose, sucrose, maltotriose, maltose, lactose, D-cellobiose, ribose, L-arabinose,D-xylose, D-arabitol, glycerol, turanose, 5-keto-D-gluconate,D-gluconate, protocatechuate, 4-hydroxybenzoate, lactate,glycerate, aspartate, glutamate, alanine, serine, and tyrosine.The cell wall contains lysine, alanine, and glutamic acid.The whole-cell sugars are galactose, glucose, ribose, and mannose. The quinone system and polar lipid and fatty acid profiles are unknown.Source: The surface of Reblochon cheese.DNA G+C content (mol%): 59.27 (genome).Type strain: Re117; CIP 108037; DSM 16368; IAM 15318;JCM 13566.10.1002/9781118960608.gbm01431
DMBP00005855	Glutamicibacter mishrai (mish’ra.i. N.L. masc. gen. n.mishrai of Mishra, in honor of late Professor Ajit K. Mishra,Bose Institute, Calcutta, India, a microbiologist in India).Cells are Gram-positive, aerobic, non-sporulating shortnon-motile rods and approximately 0.6–0.8×1.1–1.8 µmin size. DMBP00005870	172 Exiguobacterium enclense (en.clen'se. N.L. neut. adj. enclense arbitrary name formed from NCL,173 the acronym for the National Chemical laboratory, India, where taxonomic studies on this174 species were performed).175 The cells are Gram-positive, motile, non-spore forming rods to cocobacilli. Colonies grown on176 TSA medium are 1.2–1.8 mm in diameter, yellowish orange, convex with entire margin. Growth177 is observed under aerobic condition between 25 and 42° C (optimum, 28±2°C) and between pH178 6.0 and 12.0 (optimum, pH 7.0); can tolerate up to 15% NaCl (w/v). Positive for citrate179 utilization, weakly positive for β-galactosidase, and urease. Negative for lysine and ornithine180 decarboxylase, indole production, methyl red, Voges-Proskauer’s test, phenyl deamination,hydrogen sulphide (H2S), and aesculin hydrolysis. Strain NIO-1009T181 negative for starch and urea182 hydrolysis and positive for Tweens 20, 40, 60 or 80. DMBP00005894	 Bacillus crescens (cres′cens. L. part. adj. crescens arising, becoming visible, appearing, of the moon in its first quarter, crescent).Colonies are creamy white with a butyrous texture for initial 4 days which turns friable after longer incubation (>4 days). Colony elevations are flat and edges are entire with undulate margins. The diameter of coloniesis 2–3 mm after 5 days growth. Cells are rod-to-curved rods (crescent-shaped), Gram-stain-positive, 0.9–1.0 μm wide and 3.0–10.0 μm long, non-motile and multiply by binary fission. Forms sub-terminal/central endospores of cylindrical to oval shape (size 0.5–0.6 × 0.9–2.0 μm) in a swollen sporangium. Mesophilic and halotolerant. NaCl is not required for growth and is tolerated up to 5 % (w/v). Optimal growth occurs at pH 7–8 (range, pH 5.8–9.0). The temperature range for growth is 18–45 °C with optimal growth at 30–37 °C. Hydrolyses Tween 80 and starch, but not casein or gelatin. Catalase-positive and oxidase-negative. Negative result in tests for H2S production, indole production, ONPG, urease and denitrification. Growth occurs with d-galactose, d-glucose, d-fructose, cellobiose, d-mannitol, lactose, d-mannose, d-sorbitol, sucrose, pyruvate, l-aspartic acid and citrate; growth is not observed with l-rhamnose, l-fucose, d-sorbitol and l-glutamate. Acids are produced from d-glucose and sucrose, but not from cellobiose, d-galactose, l-arabinose, d-mannitol, d-fructose, Starch or d-mannose. Ammonium salts are used as a sole nitrogen source. Vitamins are not required for growth. Sensitive to fosfomycin, penicillin G, chloramphenicol, gentamicin, kanamycin, streptomycin and vancomycin, but resistant to rifampicin, polymyxin B, sulfamethoxazole, nalidixic acid and tetracycline. meso-Diaminopimelic acid is the diagnostic diamino acid. Major fatty acids (>5 %) are iso-C16 : 0, iso-C14 : 0, iso-C15 : 0, C16 : 1ω11c and C16 : 0, with minor amounts ( < 5 but >1 %) of anteiso-C15 : 0, anteiso-C17 : 0, iso-C16 : 1 H, iso-C17 : 0, iso-C18 : 0, C14 : 0, C17 : 0, C18 : 0, C18 : 1ω9c, iso-C17 : 1ω10c and anteiso-C17 : 0 B/isoI. Phosphatidylethanolamine, phosphatidylglycerol, diphosphatidylglycerol, unidentified lipids (L1–5) and unidentified aminolipids (AL1–2) are present.The type strain is JC247T ( = KCTC 33627T = LMG 28608T), isolated from a soil at Rann of Kutch, Gujarat, India. The genomic DNA G+C content of the type strain is 48.2 mol% (by HPLC). Strain JC248 has similar characters to the type train and represents an additional strain of the species with a DNA G+C content of 48.1 mol%.
DMBP00005896	Comamonas aquatica (a.qua9ti.ca. L. fem. adj. aquatica living in water).Basonym: Aquaspirillum aquaticum Hylemon et al. 1973.Gram-negative rods, motile by multitrichous polar flagella, often with bipolar tufts. Grows aerobically on tryptic soy agar and broth at 30 and 35 °C. Moderate and delayed growth in broth may be observed at 40 °C; there is no growth at 42 °C. After 24 h incubation at 30 °C, colonies reach a diameter of 1–1.5 mm on blood agar. Oxidase and catalase activities are positive. Carbohydrates are neither acidified nor assimilated. Ethylene glycol is not acidified. Urease, indole and H2S are not produced; negative for lysine decarboxylase, ornithine decarboxylase and arginine dihydrolase. Nitrates are reduced, but nitrites are not.Tyrosine and gelatin are not hydrolysed. Simmons’ citrate agar test is positive. On Simmons’ minimal agar base, Lalanine and glycine are neither assimilated nor alkalinized.Using ID 32 GN strips, propionate, valerate, 3-hydroxybutyrate, L-proline, itaconate, suberate, acetate and lactate are assimilated. Utilization of caprate and 4-hydroxybenzoate is variable. 3-Hydroxybenzoate and Lalanine are not utilized. Alkaline phosphatase, trypsin and pyrrolidone arylamidase are negative. Strains are susceptible to desferrioxamine and colistin. The main cellular fatty acids are C16 : 1, C16 : 0, C18 : 1v9c, C10 : 0 3-OH, C12 : 0 and C14 : 0.The DNA G+C content is 62.8–66.7 mol%.The type strain is LMG 2370T (=CCUG 15845T=ATCC11330T). Its DNA G+C content is 64.0 mol%. The sequence of its 16S rDNA is available under EMBL/GenBank accession number AJ430344.10.1099/ijs.0.02450-0
DMBP00005903	Comamonas terrae sp. nov. (terʼrae. L. gen. n. terra of the earth) Aerobic, Gram-negative rods. Motile by a polar flagellum. Colonies were circular, formed white, raised with entire margins, 1‒2.5 mm diameter, without pigmentation. Non spore. Non-fermentative. Positive in tests for catalase, oxidase, utilization of citrate, urease, VP and hydrolysis of esculin. Grows at 40°C in the presence of 4.5% (w/v) NaCl and at pH 5 to11 but not at 4 or 50°C, in the presence of 5% (w/v) NaCl or at pH 4. Positive assimilation for potassium gluconate, adipate and malate. Negative in tests for MR, amino acid decarboxylase (ADH, LDC, ODC), ONPG, hydrolysis of TDA, lysine, arginine, gelatin, starch, Tween 80; indole, nitrate reduction; H2S production, and oxidation of glycerol. Negative assimilation for D-adonitol, amygdalin, arbutin, D-arabitol, L-arabitol, D-arabinose, L-arabinose, D-cellobiose, dulcitol, erythritol, D-fructose, D-fucose, L-fucose, D-galactose, gentiobiose, glycogen, D-glucose, inositol, inulin, melibiose, methyl-β-D-xylopyranoside, D-lactose, D-lyxose, D-mannose, D-mannitol, methyl-α- D-mannopyranoside, methyl -α-D-glucopyranoside, Nacetylglucosamine, D-maltose, D-melezitose, D-melibiose, D-raffi nose, L-rhamnose, D-ribose, salicin, L-sorbose, D-sorbitol, starch, sucrose, D-trehalose, D-tagatose, Dturanose, xylitol, D-xylose, L-xylose, potassium 2-ketogluconate, potassium 5-ketogluconate, caprate, citrate and phenyl acetic acid. Susceptible to carbenicillin, erythromycin, gentamicin, imipenem, kanamycin, sulphonamide, tetracycline, and tobramycin but resistant to ampicillin, bacitracin, cephalothin, clindamycin, penicillin and vancomycin. DNA G+C content is 69.6 mol%. The major quinone is ubiquinone-8 and major cellular fatty acids are C16:0 and C17:0 CYCLO. The type strain is A3-3T (=KCTC 22606T =NBRC 106524T =PCU 324T =TISTR 1906T).10.2323/jgam.58.245
DMBP00005924	Cells of strains IMMIB D-771T and IMMIB AL-1155 grown on Loewenstein-Jensen medium and on Middlebrook 7H10 agar were rod shaped, gram positive, and acid-alcohol fast. Spores, capsules, true branching, and aerial hyphae were not observed. At 24 to 45°C growth occurred within 1 to 2 days on Loewenstein-Jensen medium, Middlebrook 7H10 agar, and brain heart infusion agar. Dilute inocula on Loewenstein-Jensen medium, Middlebrook 7H10 agar, and brain heart infusion agar yielded large, eugonic, brownish orange, rough colonies. The physiological properties of strains IMMIB D-771T and IMMIB AL-1155 are shown in Table 1. These strains exhibited acetamidase, allantoinase, catalase, β-glucosidase, β-galactosidase, nicotinamidase, pyrazinamidase, urease, and phosphatase activities; arylsulfatase, benzamidase, nitrate reductase, and succinamidase activities were not observed. Strains IMMIB D-771T and IMMIB AL-1155 did not produce niacin but tolerated 5% NaCl and p-nitrobenzoic acid. The resistance of both strains to all of the antituberculous drugs tested was characteristic (Table 1). Table 1 shows that the two strains are very similar. The only difference is that strain IMMIB D-771T is able to utilize cellobiose as a sole carbon source while strain IMMIB AL-1155 does not assimilate this sugar.

DMBP00005931	Heyndrickxia (Heyn.drickx’i.a. N.L. fem. n. Heyndrickxia, named for Prof. Marc Heyndrickx (University of Gent) for his many contributions to Microbiology and studies on Bacillus species).Aerobic rod-shaped bacteria. Most species are Gram-negative except B. sporothermodurans, which shows Gram-positive staining. All species form endospores and most are motile. Mainly isolated from dairy sources (raw milk and feed concentrate for cattle). Generally, catalase- and oxidase-positive. Temperature range for growth is 20–55 °C, with optimum growth in the range 30–45 °C. Members of this genus form a monophyletic clade in phylogenetic trees based on concatenated sequences for several large datasets of proteins. In addition, the members of this genus can be reliably distinguished from all other Bacillaceae species by the five CSIs described in Table 5 in the following proteins: stage V sporulation protein D, N-acetyl-gamma-glutamyl-phosphate reductase, type II/IV secretion system protein, homoserine O-succinyltransferase and septation ring formation regulator EzrA, which in most cases are exclusively shared by either all or most members of this genus. The type species is Heyndrickxia oleronius.(vi’ni. L. gen. neut. n. vini of wine, referring to the isolation of the type strain from pit mud of a Luzhou-flavour liquor alcohol fermentation in Sichuan Province, China).Basonym: Bacillus vini Ma et al. 2017The description of this species is the same as provided by Ma et al. [115] for Bacillus vini.Type strain: LAM0415=JCM 19841=ACCC 06413.10.1099/ijsem.0.004475

DMBP00005936	 Herbaspirillum robiniae (ro.bi′ni.ae. N.L. gen. n. robiniae of Robinia).Cells are aerobic, Gram-stain-negative, motile and slightly curved- and rod-shaped (0.3×1.0–2.0 µm) with two polar flagella. Strain HZ10T grows well at 28 °C on YMA, LB and TSA. Colonies grown on YMA for 2 days are brownish, convex, circular and 3–5 mm in diameter. Growth occurs at 4–45 °C (optimum: 25–30 °C), pH 5–9 (optimum: pH 7–8) and 0–1 % (w/v) NaCl. Catalase activity is positive. H2S is not produced. The methyl red reaction is negative. Likewise, it is negative for arginine dual water dielectric enzymes and assimilation of adipic acid, phenylacetic acid, d-arabinose, ribitol, sorbitol, xylitol and l-arabitol. The major fatty acids are C16 : 0, summed feature 8 (C18 : 1ω7c and/or C18 : 1ω6c) and summed feature 3 (C16 : 1ω7c and/or C16 : 1ω6c). The quinone type is Q-8. The major polar lipids are diphosphatidylglycerol, phosphatidylethanolamine and phosphatidylglycerol.The type strain, HZ10T (=JCM 31754T=CCTCC AB 2014352T), was isolated from root nodules of Robinia pseudoacacia growing in a lead–zinc mine in Mianxian County, Shaanxi Province, China. DMBP00006124	 Novosphingobium colocasiae [co.lo.ca′si.ae. L. n. Colocasia the name of a botanical genus (taro); L. gen. n. colocasiae of taro, denoting the isolation of the type strain from taro].Cells are Gram-stain-negative, aerobic, non-spore-forming, non-motile, rod-shaped and chemo-heterotrophic. Oxidase- and catalase-positive. Negative for poly-β-hydroxybutyrate accumulation. After 48 h of incubation on R2A agar at 30 °C, cells are approximately 0.3–0.5 μm in diameter and 0.8–1.0 μm in length. Colonies are bright yellow, convex, round and smooth with entire edges. Colony diameter is approximately 1.0–1.9 mm on R2A agar after 48 h of incubation at 30 °C. Growth occurs at 10–37 °C (optimum, 20 °C), with 0–1.0 % (w/v) NaCl (optimum, 0 %) and at pH 3.0–9.0 (optimum, pH 7.0–8.0). Positive for hydrolysis of CM-cellulose and Tweens 40 and 60. Negative for hydrolysis of urea, starch, gelatin, DNA, casein, chitin, corn oil and Tweens 20 and 80. In API 20NE tests, positive reactions for aesculin hydrolysis and assimilation of glucose and maltose, and negative reactions for nitrate reduction, indole production, glucose fermentation, arginine dihydrolase, urease and β-galactosidase activities, gelatin hydrolysis, and assimilation of arabinose, mannose, mannitol, N-acetylglucosamine, gluconate, caprate, adipate, malate, citrate and phenyl-acetate. The following compounds are utilized as sole carbon sources in the GN2 microplate: dextrin, Tween 80, cellobiose, d-fructose, α-d-glucose, sucrose, pyruvic acid methyl ester, succinic acid monomethyl ester, acetic acid, β-hydroxybutyric acid, α-ketobutyric acid, α-ketoglutaric acid, α-ketovaleric acid, dl-lactic acid, bromosuccinic acid, succinamic acid, l-alaninamide, d-alanine, l-alanine, l-alanyl glycine, l-asparagine, l-glutamic acid, glycyl l-aspartic acid, glycyl l-glutamic acid, l-leucine, l-ornithine and l-proline. All other substrates in the GN2 microplate are not utilized. Resistant to sulfamethoxazole/trimethoprim, streptomycin and nalidixic acid, but sensitive to rifampicin, chloramphenicol, gentamicin, kanamycin, tetracycline, novobiocin, penicillin G and ampicillin. The major fatty acids (>10 %) are C18 : 1ω7c, summed feature 3 (C16 : 1ω7c and/or C16 : 1ω6c) and C16 : 0. The polar lipid profile consists of phosphatidylglycerol, phosphatidylethanolamine, phosphatidylmonomethylethanolamine, phosphatidyldimethylethanolamine, sphingoglycolipid, phosphatidylcholine, an uncharacterized glycolipid and an uncharacterized aminolipid. The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 65.0 mol%.
DMBP00006177	Bacteroides thetaiotaomicron (Distaso 1912) Castellani and Chalmers 1919, 960AL [Bacillus thetaiotaomicron Distaso 1912, 444; Sphaerocillus thetaiotaomicron (Distaso 1912) Prévot 1938, 300; Bacteroides fragilis subsp. thetaiotaomicron (Distaso 1912) Holdeman and Moore 1970, 35]...................................................................................the.ta.i.o.ta.o’mi.cron. N.L. n. thetaiotaomicron a combination of the Greek letters theta, iota and omicron (relating to the morphology of vacuolated forms).Characteristics are as described for the genus and as given in Table 2, with the following additional characteristics. Cells are pleomorphic and occur singly or in pairs. Cells from blood agar plates or PY broth are smaller and more homogeneous in size and shape than cells from media with a fermentable carbohydrate. Capsules are present in some strains. Surface colonies on blood agar are punctiform, circular, entire, convex, semiopaque, whitish, soft, and shiny. Sheep blood is not hemolyzed. Hemin is either required or is highly stimulatory for growth. The major fatty acids are C15:0 anteiso, C17:0 iso 3-OH, C18:1 ω9c, and C16:0 3-OH. The genome of Bacteroides thetaiotaomicron VPI-5482 has been sequenced. The genome of Bacteroides fragilis NCTC 9343T contains a single circular chromosome of 6,260,361bp. The genome has large expansions of many paralogous groups of genes that encode products essential to the organism’s ability to successfully compete in the human colonic microbiota. Most notable of these is the organism’s abundant machinery for utilizing a large variety of complex polysaccharides as a source of carbon and energy. The proteome also reveals the organism’s extensive ability to adapt andregulate expression of its genes in response to the changing ecosystem. These factors suggest a highly flexible and adaptable organism that is exquisitely equipped to dominate in its challenging and competitive niche (Xu et al., 2003).Source: human feces, frequently found in human clinical specimens.DNA G+C content (mol %): 40–43 (HPLC).Type strain: ATCC 29148, CCUG 10774, CIP 104206, DSM 2079, JCM 5827, NCTC 10582, VPI 5482.Sequence accession no. DMBP00006333	Bacillus oryzaecorticis (o.ry.zae.cor′ti.cis. L. fem. n. oryza rice; L. masc. n. cortex bark, husk; N.L. masc. gen. n. oryzaecorticis of rice husk).Forms orange, slightly raised colonies on TSA at 37 °C. Cells are Gram-stain-positive rods (0.3–0.5×1.5–2.5 µm), aerobic and endospore-forming. Endospores are spherical or ellipsoidal and lie at subterminal positions in swollen sporangia. Growth occurs at 15–45 °C (optimum 37 °C), at pH 4.5–10.0 (optimum pH 6.0–7.0), but not at pH 4.0. Growth occurs in the presence of 0–9 % (w/v) NaCl. Catalase- and oxidase-positive. Tests for β-galactosidase, arginine dihydrolase, lysine decarboxylase, ornithine decarboxylase, H2S production, urease, tryptophan deaminase, indole production, and gelatinase are negative. Cells are susceptible to paper discs containing the following antibiotics (µg per disc): ampicillin (10), chloramphenicol (30), erythromycin (15), gentamicin (30), neomycin (30), penicillin G (10), streptomycin (10), tetracycline (30) and vancomycin (30). Contains MK-5 (50 %) and MK-7 (50 %) as the predominant menaquinones, and PG, DPG and PE as the major polar lipids. The diagnostic diamino acid in the peptidoglycan is meso-diaminopimelic acid. The major cellular fatty acids are iso-C15 : 0 and anteiso-C15 : 0.The type strain, R1T ( = KACC 17217T = KCCM 90231T = JCM 19602T), was isolated from rice husks from the Republic of Korea.
DMBP00006368	"Nocardia cyriacigeorgici (cy.ri.a.ci.ge.or«gi.ci. Gr. neut. n. kyriako’n house of the lord, church; M.L. neut. n. cyriacum, cyriaci church; Gr. adj. georgikos related to agriculture, related to St George; M.L. adj. georgicus of St George; M.L. adj. cyriacigeorgici of St George’s church, referring to the origin of the name of the German town Gelsenkirchen where the type strain was isolated). Hyphae are Gram-positive and slightly acid-alcoholfast. The vegetative hyphae are well-developed with irregular branches penetrating the agar and bear white aerial hyphae. At a late stage of growth, the hyphae fragment into rod-shaped elements. The organism contains meso-diaminopimelic acid, galactose and arabinose in whole-cell hydrolysates (i.e. cell wall chemotype IV). It has mycolic acids with 46–54 carbon atoms and 0–3 double bonds (C%':! , C%':$ , C%):! , C%):$ , C&!:! , C&!:"" , C&!:$ , C&#:! , C&#:"" and C&%:"" ) that are cleaved on pyrolysis to release fatty acids with C""%:! , C""':! , C""):"" and C""):! carbon atoms with C""':! as the major cleavage product; thus Nocardia cyriacigeorgici has a cellular fatty acid profile that comprises saturated, unsaturated and 10-methyl branched fatty acids. Possesses type PII phospholipids with significant amounts of phosphatidylethanolamine. The menaquinone system consists of partially saturated menaquinones with eight isoprene units, in which the two terminal isoprene moieties are cyclized; MK-8(H' ) is the major menaquinone and minor amounts of 2,3-epoxy-MK-8(H' ) are also present. It hydrolyses aesculin, testosterone and urea but not adenine, casein, elastin, gelatin, guanine, hypoxanthine, keratin, tyrosine or xanthine. Assimilates acetate, gluconate, sucrose and paraffin as carbon sources but not adipate, benzoate, citrate, lactate, arabinose, cellobiose, galactose, glucose, lactose, maltose, melezitose, raffinose, rhamnose, trehalose, xylose, adonitol, meso-erythritol, myo-inositol, mannitol, sorbitol, isoamyl alcohol, 2,3- butanediol, 1,2-propanediol, m-hydroxybenzoate or phydroxybenzoate. Utilizes acetamide, but not alanine, gelatin, proline or serine, as simultaneous carbon and nitrogen sources. The G¬C content of the DNA is 68.1 mol%. The type strain is IMMIB D-1627T (= DSM 44484T), which was isolated from the bronchial secretion of a patient suffering from chronic bronchitis."

DMBP00006471	 Mammaliicoccus vitulinus (vi.tu.li′nus. L. masc. adj. vitulinus, of a calf).Basonym: Staphylococcus vitulinus corrig. Webster et al. 1994.The description is the same as for Staphylococcus vitulinus corrig [53]. Phylogenomic analyses of the core genome provided strong evidence for assignment of this species in the novel genus Mammaliicoccus. The DNA G+C content (mol%) of the type strain genome is 32.5 %, its approximate genome size is 2.60 Mbp, its GenBank accession is GCA_002902265.1. The type strain is DD 756T (=ATCC 51145T=CCM 4511T=CCUG 33636T=CIP 104850T=DSM 15615T). Mammaliicoccus [Mam.ma.li.i.coc′cus. N.L. neut. pl. n. Mammalia mammals; N.L. masc. n. coccus (from Gr. masc. n. kokkos) a berry, a coccus; N.L. masc. n. Mammaliicoccus a coccus from mammals]. The description is based on previous data [48–52] and from the present study. Cells are Gram-positive, non-motile, non-spore-forming cocci that occur singly, in pairs, and irregular clusters. Aerobic to facultative anaerobic growth. Catalase-positive with variable oxidase activities. The DNA G+C content (mol%) ranges from 31.6 to 35.7 and the genome size ranges from 2.44 to 2.81 Mbp.The description is as for Mammaliicoccus sciuri comb. nov., which is the type species. The genus has been separated from Staphylococcus based on analyses of 16S rRNA gene sequences, whole genome phylogenies, and overall genome related indices.10.1099/ijsem.0.004498
DMBP00006480	 Psychrobacillus lasiicapitis (la.si.i.ca′pi.tis. N.L. masc. n. Lasius an ant genus: L. neut. n. caput, capitis head; N.L. gen. n. lasiicapitis of the head of a Lasius ant).Cells are Gram-stain-positive, strictly aerobic, spore-forming, rod-shaped (1.9–2.1×0.6–0.7 µm) and motile by means of peritrichous flagella. Growth occurs at 0–35 °C (optimum, 28–30 °C), at pH 6.0–11.0 (optimum, 7.0–8.0) and with ≤6 % (w/v) NaCl (optimum, 0 %). Grows well on TSA but weakly on NA. Positive for reduction of nitrate, hydrolysis of Tweens 20, 40 and 80 and production of urease. Negative for Voges–Proskauer reaction, methyl red test, hydrolysis of starch and aesculin, peptonization and coagulation of milk, decomposition of cellulose, citrate utilization and liquefaction of gelatin. Utilizes d-glucose, maltose, raffinose, sucrose, d-xylose and inositol as sole carbon sources but not d-mannitol, d-sorbitol, d-ribose or lactose. Utilizes l-arginine, l-proline and creatine as sole carbon and nitrogen sources, but not l-aspartic acid, l-glutamic acid, l-serine, l-threonine or l-tyrosine. The main phospholipids are diphosphatidylglycerol, phosphatidylethanolamine and phosphatidylglycerol. The cell-wall peptidoglycan type is A4β with ornithine as the diamino acid in position 3. The primary menaquinone is MK-8 with some MK-7. The major cellular fatty acids (>5 %) are iso-C14 : 0, anteiso-C15 : 0, C16 : 0 and iso-C15 : 0. In the API 20NE tests, positive for the reduction of nitrate, urease and oxidase. No acid production in API 50CH panels. In API ZYM strips, positive for alkaline phosphatase, esterase (C4), esterase lipase (C8), naphthol-AS-BI-phosphohydrolase, acid phosphatase, leucine arylamidase and valine arylamidase; negative for α-chymotrypsin, cystine arylamidase, α-fucosidase, α-galactosidase, β-galactosidase, β-glucuronidase, α-glucosidase, β-glucosidase, N-acetyl-β-glucosaminidase, leucine arylamidase, lipase (C14), α-mannosidase and trypsin.The type strain, NEAU-3TGS17T (=DSM 100484T=CGMCC 1.15308T), was isolated from the head of L. fuliginosus collected from Northeast Agriculture University (Harbin, Heilongjiang, China). The G+C content of the DNA of the type strain is 35.8 mol%.
DMBP00006482	 Psychrobacillus glaciei (gla.ci.e'i. L. gen. n. glaciei of ice, from which the type strain was isolated).Cells are Gram-stain-positive, strictly aerobic, spore-forming rods that are 0.3–0.4 µm in diameter and 3.0–5.0 µm long. They exhibit gliding motility. Colonies on LB are circular and pale white–yellow. The temperature range for growth is −2–30 °C (optimum, 15 °C). The cells grow in LB broth at pH 5.0–8.0 (optimum, pH 7.0) and in the presence of 0–8.0 % (w/v) NaCl (optimum, 0 %). They exhibit catalase and oxidase activities, and degrade Tweens 40 and 80, but not DNA, starch, gelatin or Tween 20. All enzymatic reactions are negative according to the API 20NE kit. Test results for the assimilation of d-glucose, d-mannitol, maltose, potassium gluconate and malic acid are positive, but are negative for the assimilation of l-arabinose, d-mannose, capric acid, N-acetyl-glucosamine, capric acid, adipic acid, trisodium citrate and phenylacetic acid. According to the API ZYM kit, esterase (C4), esterase lipase (C8), leucine arylamidase, valine arylamidase, cystine arylamidase, trypsin, α-chymotrypsin, naphthol-AS-BI-phosphohydrolase, α-glucosidase and β-fucosidase activities are positive, but alkaline phosphatase, lipase (C14), acid phosphatase, α-galactosidase, β-galactosidase, β-glucuronidase, β-glucosidase, N -acetyl-β-glucosaminidase, α-mannosidase and arginine dihydrolase activities are negative. The predominant cellular fatty acids are iso-C15 : 0, anteiso-C15 : 0 and C16 : 1 ω7c alcohol. The major polar lipid is phosphatidylethanolamine; also present are one diphosphatidylglycerol, two uncharacterized aminolipids and four uncharacterized lipids. MK-8 is the major respiratory quinone. The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 36.0 mol%. The type strain is PB01T (=CECT 9792T=KCTC 43041T), isolated from a sample collected from an Antarctic iceberg near the King Sejong Station on King George Island, Antarctica.
DMBP00006483	 Psychrobacillus vulpis (vul′pis. L. gen. n. vulpis, of a fox).Cells are rod, Gram-stain-positive, motile, facultative anaerobic and able to sporulate. Endospores in swollen sporangia are central and rounded with a size range of 0.8–0.9×0.8–0.9 µm. Colonies are transparent-grey, vortex-like shape and invade all of the plate after 5 days of incubation at 28 °C. Slightly halophilic bacteria with a NaCl range from 0 to 5.5 % (w/v) and an optimum at 2.5 % (w/v). Able to grow in a pH range of pH 6–10 and from 0 to 37 °C, with optima at pH 7 and 28 °C. Positive for catalase, oxidase and H2S production and negative for Voges–Proskauer and indole production. Starch, Tween 20, Tween 80, DNA and l-tyrosine are hydrolysed, but not cellulose, casein, gelatine, chitin, haem and aesculin. Positive for both alkaline and acid phosphatases, and siderophores production. Nitrate reduction is positive but negative for arginine dehydrolase, β-galactosidase (PNPG) and urease. No assimilation was detected for any API 20NE compound except for N-acetylglucosamine, malate and adipic acid. Positive for esterase (C4) and for esterase lipase (C8), leucine arylamidase, trypsin, α-chymotrypsin and naphthol-AS-BI-phosphohydrolase. Weakly positive for valine arylamidase. No acid production from any substrate in the API 50CH assay kit. The major cellular fatty acids are iso-C14 : 0, iso-C15 : 0 and anteiso-C15 : 0. The main polar lipids are diphosphatidylglycerol, phosphatidylethanolamine and phosphatidylglycerol, and the main respiratory isoprenoid quinone is MK-8 with a lower amount of MK-7. The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 35.9 mol%.The type strain is Z8T (=CECT 9721T=LMG 31001T), isolated from red fox (Vulpes vulpes) faeces collected in Las Tablas de Daimiel National Park, Ciudad Real, Spain.
DMBP00006525	Asaia lannaensis (lan.na.en’sis. Lanna: L. fem. suffix -ensis indicating geographical origin; N. L. fem. adj. lannaensis of or pertaining to Lanna, the old name of the region including Chiang Mai, Northern Thailand, Thailand, where the type strain was isolated). Cells are Gram-negative and rod-shaped, measuring 0.6-1.0*1.0-2.0µm on glucose/ethanol/calcium carbonate agar. Peritrichous flagella when motile. Colonies are pink, shiny, smooth, and raised with an entire margin on glucose/ethanol/calcium carbonate agar. Grows at pH 3.0 and 3.5. However, maximum growth occurs at pH 5.5. Grows on 30% glucose (w/v). No growth in the presence of either 0.35% acetic acid (v/v) or 1.0% potassium nitrate (w/v). Methanol is not assimilated as sole carbon source. Oxidizes acetate and lactate to carbon dioxide and water, but the activity is not intense. Acetic acid is produced on ethanol/calcium carbonate agar. Produces 2-keto-D-gluconate and 5-keto-D-gluconate, but not 2,5-diketo-D-gluconate from D-glucose. Grows on glutamate agar and mannitol agar. Grows on a vitamin-free glucose/ammonium sulfate medium, but not on ethanol/ammonium sulfate medium. Produces dihydroxyacetone from glycerol, but the activity is not intense. Acid is produced from D-glucose, D-mannose, D-galactose, D-fructose, L-sorbose, D-xylose, D-arabinose (weakly positive), L-arabinose, L-rhamnose, D-mannitol, D-sorbitol (weakly positive), dulcitol (weakly positive), D-arabitol, L-arabitol (weakly positive), meso-ribitol, meso-erythritol, glycerol, melibiose, sucrose (weakly positive in isolate AB92T), raffinose (weakly positive in isolate AB92T but negative in AB93), or ethanol (weakly positive), but not from maltose. Grows on Dglucose, D-mannose, D-galactose, D-fructose, L-sorbose, D-xylose, D-arabinose, L-arabinose, L-rhamnose, D-mannitol, D-sorbitol, dulcitol, D-arabitol, L-arabitol (weakly positive in isolate AB93), meso-ribitol, meso-erythritol, glycerol, melibiose, sucrose (weakly positive in isolate AB92T), raffinose (weakly positive in isolate AB92T but negative in AB93), or ethanol (weakly positive), but not on maltose or lactose. Shows 16S rDNA restriction group F-type of patterns. The major ubiquinone is Q-10. DNA G+C contents are 60.8–60.9 mol %, with a range of 0.1 mol %. The type strain, AB92T, which was isolated from a flower of spider lily collected in Chiang Mai, Thailand, has a DNA G+C content of 60.8 mol %. The type strain is deposited in BIOTEC Culture Collection (BCC), National Center for Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology (BIOTEC), Pathumthani, Thailand, as BCC 15733T, and in the culture collection of The National Biological Resource Center (NBRC), Department of Biotechnology, National Institute of Technology and Evaluation, Kisarazu, Chiba, Japan, as NBRC 102526T
DMBP00006532	Pseudochrobactrum kiredjianiae (ki.red.ji.a′ni.ae. N.L. fem. gen. n. kiredjianiae of Kiredjian, named after Martine Kiredjian, a contemporary French microbiologist, for her numerous contributions to the taxonomy of Ochrobactrum and related organisms).Shares all characteristics listed in the genus description. Good growth occurs on R2A agar, TSA, nutrient agar and MacConkey agar at 25–30 °C. Beige, translucent and shiny colonies with entire edges form within 24 h, with a diameter of approximately 2 mm. Quinone system is ubiquinone Q-10 (99 %) and Q-9 (1 %). The polar lipid profile consists of the major components phosphatidylethanolamine, phosphatidylglycerol, diphosphatidylglycerol and phosphatidylcholine, moderate amounts of phosphatidylmonomethylethanolamine and unknown aminolipid AL1 and trace amounts of three unknown lipids. Polyamine profile consists of spermidine [60.3 μmol (g dry weight)−1], putrescine [42.7 μmol (g dry weight)−1], 1,3-diaminopropane [2.0 μmol (g dry weight)−1] and spermine [1.5 μmol (g dry weight)−1]. Carbon source utilization and hydrolysis of chromogenic substrates (including characteristics that differentiate Ochrobactrum species) are given in Table 2T2.The type strain is CCUG 49584T (=CIP 109227T), which was isolated in 1995 from a stainless-steel vent cover, from a seafood processing plant in Nelson, New Zealand.
DMBP00006604	 Limosilactobacillus reuteri subsp. reuteri (reu′te.ri. N.L. gen. n. reuteri, of Reuter; named for G. Reuter, a German bacteriologist after whom the species L. reuteri was named).L. reuteri strains clustered in lineage II (Fig. 3) belong to L. reuteri subsp. reuteri and they were isolated from humans and herbivores [7, 43]. Strains of this subspecies have ANI values of 98.1–100.0 % with each other and ANI values of 94.0–96.5 % with other L. reuteri strains belonging to different subspecies (Fig. 4). Acid is produced from l-arabinose, d-ribose, d-galactose, d-glucose, maltose, lactose, melibiose, sucrose and raffinose; acid production from potassium gluconate is strain-specific; acid is not produced from d-xylose, d-fructose, d-mannose, methyl α-d-glucopyranoside, aesculin, glycerol, erythritol, d-arabinose, l-xylose, d-adonitol, methyl β-d-xylopyranoside, l-sorbose, l-rhamnose, dulcitol, inositol, d-mannitol, d-sorbitol, methyl α-d-mannopyranoside, N-acetylglucosamine, amygdalin, arbutin, salicin, cellobiose, trehalose, inulin, melezitose, starch, glycogen, xylitol, gentiobiose, turanose, d-lyxose, d-tagatose, d-fucose, l-fucose, d-arabitol, l-arabitol, potassium 2-ketogluconate or potassium 5-ketogluconate. Phylogenetic analyses based on the core genes identified in this study (Fig. 3) and previous studies [5, 43], AFLP and MLSA (using concatenated sequences of ddl, pkt, leuS, gyrB, dltA, rpoA and recA genes) [7], suggest that these strains are genetically homogeneous [8]. Strains of this subspecies possess the pdu-cbi-cob-hem cluster (pdu cluster) [6, 8], which equips them with the ability to utilize 1,2-propanediol and glycerol as electron acceptors [16, 39, 40] and to produce the antimicrobial compound reuterin [8]. They also produce histamine from histidine that has been linked to their anti-inflammatory phenotype [34]. Strains belonging to this subspecies have been considered as immunosuppressive because they could suppress the proinflammatory cytokines tumour necrosis factor (TNF), monocyte chemoattractant protein (MCP)-1, interleukin (IL)-1β and IL-12, as well as suppress intestinal inflammation [34]. The type strain, DSM 20016T (=ATCC 23272T=F 275T [original designation]), was isolated from the gastrointestinal tract of an adult human [6, 44, 45], with a DNA G+C content of 38.9 mol%.10.1099/ijsem.0.004644
DMBP00006634	 Sphingobium naphthae sp. nov. (naph′thae. Gr. n. naphtha oil; N.L. gen. n. naphthae of oil).Cells are Gram-stain-negative, aerobic, non-motile, non-spore-forming rods. Cells are 0.6–0.8 µm wide and 1.0–1.2 µm long. Colonies are 0.5–1.0 mm in diameter after incubation on R2A agar at 28 °C for 5 days. Colonies on R2A agar are light yellow, circular, smooth, convex and opaque with entire margins. Cells grow well on R2A agar, VIA, LBA, TSA and marine agar; poorly on NA and BHI agar; and do not grow on MA. Cell growth occurs at 15–45 °C (optimum, 20–40 °C) and pH 5.0–9.5 (optimum, 6.5–7.5). Cells grow optimally in the absence of NaCl but can tolerate up to 6 % (w/v) NaCl. Positive for oxidase but negative for catalase, H2S production, indole production and MR-VP tests. Hydrolyses casein, Tween 40, Tween 80, aesculin, gelatin and DNA, but not starch, CM-cellulose, tyrosine or chitin. Using the API ZYM test kit, cells are positive for alkaline phosphatase, esterase (C4), leucine arylamidase, valine arylamidase, cystine arylamidase, trypsin, α-chymotrypsin, acid phosphatase, naphthol-AS-BI-phosphohydrolase, β-galactosidase, α-glucosidase and β-glucosidase; weakly positive for α-galactosidase and β-glucuronidase; and negative for esterase lipase (C8), lipase (C14), N-acetyl-β-glucosaminidase, α-mannosidase and α-fucosidase. In API 20NE tests, positive for nitrate reduction, gelatin, aesculin ferric citrate and 4-nitrophenyl-β-d-galactopyranoside. Negative for fermentation of glucose, l-tryptophan, l-arginine and urea. Cells assimilate d-glucose, l-arabinose, d-mannose, N-acetylglucosamine, maltose, potassium gluconate and malic acid, but not d-mannitol, capric acid, adipic acid, trisodium citrate or phenylacetic acid. Utilizes l-rhamnose, sucrose, maltose, sodium acetate, l-alanine, d-glucose, l-arabinose, l-histidine, 3-hydroxybutyric acid and 4-hydroxybenzoic acid; weakly utilizes lactic acid, l-serine and l-proline; and cannot utilize N-acetylglucosamine, d-ribose, inositol, itaconic acid, suberic acid, sodium malonate, potassium 5-ketogluconate, glycogen, 3-hydroxybenzoic acid, d-mannitol, salicin, melibiose, l-fucose, d-sorbitol, propionic acid, capric acid, valeric acid, trisodium citrate or potassium 2-ketogluconate (API ID 32GN). Q-10 is the predominant respiratory quinone and spermidine is the major polyamine. The major polar lipids present are phosphatidylethanolamine, phosphatidylglycerol, diphosphatidylglycerol, phosphatidylcholine, phosphatidyldimethylethanolamine, sphingoglycolipid and phosphatidylmonomethylethanolamine. The major fatty acids are summed feature 8 (C18 : 1ω7c and/or C18 : 1ω6c), summed feature 3 (C16 : 1ω7c and/or C16 : 1ω6c), C14 : 0, C16 : 0 and C14 : 0 2-OH.The type strain, K-3-6T (=KEMB 9005-449T=KACC 19001T=JCM 31713T), was isolated from oil-contaminated soil of Biratnagar, Morang, Nepal. The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 65.6 mol%.

Ubiquinone 10 is the majorquinone type. Predominant fatty acids are 18 : 1v7c and19 : 0 cyclo v8c. The type strain is strain S1T (5CIP106844T 5DSM 11099T).10.1099/ijs.0.008730-0

DMBP00006681	 Micromonospora sediminis (se.di′mi.nis. L. gen. n. sediminis of sediment).Gram-stain-positive, aerobic, mesophilic actinomycete which forms branched substrate mycelium. Aerial mycelium is absent. Monomeric spores are observed on substrate mycelium. Colonies appear dark greyish-yellow on ISP2, ISP4 and marine agar media; pale yellow on ISP3 and nutrient media; moderate yellow on ISP5 medium and greyish yellow and light yellow on ISP5 and ISP7 media, respectively. Nitrate is reduced to nitrite. Hydrolysis of starch is positive but liquefaction of gelatin is negative. Utilizes l-arabinose, cellobiose, galactose, d-mannitol, l-rhamnose and sucrose; weakly utilizes salicin and d-xylose but does not utilize fructose, myo-inositol, raffinose or ribose. Shows activities of α-chymotrypsin, esterase (C4), α-glucosidase, leucine arylamidase; weakly positive activities of acid phosphatase, esterase lipase (C8), β-galactosidase, β-glucosidase, napthol-AS-BI-phosphohydrolase and trypsin; and no activites of N-acetyl-β-glucosaminidase, alkaline phosphatase, cystine arylamidase, α-fucosidase, α-galactosidase, β-glucuronidase, lipase (C14), α-mannosidase or valine arylamidase. Growth is observed at pH 7–9 and at 28–37 °C. The maximum concentration of NaCl for growth is 2 % (w/v). Cell-wall peptidoglycan contains meso-DAP . Whole-cell sugars are glucose, mannose, xylose, ribose and rhamnose. The N-acyl type of cell-wall muramic acids is glycolyl. Mycolic acids are absent. Polar lipids are PE, PI, DPG, PG, an unidentified phospholipid, three unidentified glycolipids and two unidentified lipids. Menaquinones are MK-10(H4), MK-10(H6) and MK-10(H8). Major cellular fatty acids are iso-C15 : 0, iso-C16 :﻿ 0 and iso-C17 : 0.The type strain, CH3-3T (=JCM 18523T=PCU 350 T=TISTR 2396T), was isolated from mangrove sediment collected from Chonburi Province, Thailand. The genomic DNA G+C content of the type strain is 73.8 mol%.10.1099/ijsem.0.001175

DMBP00006773	无文献
DMBP00006779	Ureibacillus suwonensis (su.won.en′sis. N.L. masc. adj. suwonensis referring to Suwon Region in Korea, where the bacteria were first found).Cells are Gram-negative, spore-forming rods, 0·5–0·7×1·5–2·0 μm in size, single or in chains. Cells form spherical or oval spores, occurring subterminally or terminally in swollen sporangia. Cells are peritrichously flagellated and motile. Clear colonies are not formed. Colonies grow smeared. Growth occurs at temperatures ranging from 35 to 60 °C and in the presence of 5 % NaCl. Positive for catalase, oxidase and arginine dihydrolase. Weak reaction for phenylalanine deamination. Negative for anaerobic growth, formation of indole and dihydroxyacetone, VP test, nitrate reduction, acid production from d-glucose, l-arabinose, d-xylose and d-mannitol and hydrolysis of aesculin, starch, gelatin, casein and urea. The cross-linkage of peptidoglycan is l-lys←d-Asp type (variation A4α). The major cellular fatty acid is i-C16 : 0. The major isoprenoid quinones are MK-9, MK-8 and MK-7. The DNA G+C content of the type strain 6T19T is 41·5 mol%.The type strain, 6T19T (=KACC 11287T=DSM 16752T), was isolated from cotton composts in Suwon, Korea.
DMBP00006783	Macrococcus bohemicus sp. nov. (bo.he'mi.cus. N.L. masc. adj. bohemicus, pertaining to Bohemia, a region of the Czech Republic where the type strain was isolated).Cells are Gram-stain positive spherical cocci, occurring predominantly in pairs and tetrads, non-spore forming and non-motile. Colonies on TSA agar are circular, with whole margins, flat with convex center, lustreless, 1-2 mm in diameter, aerobic and nonpigmented. No Haemolytic activity. Grows in the presence of 7.5% NaCl, at 10°C and 42°C but not at 5 or 45°C. Growth in thioglycolate medium. No growth in the presence of 10% or more NaCl. Catalase, oxidase, nitrate reduction, Voges-Proskauer test (acetoin) and hydrolysis of gelatin positive. Coagulase, clumping factor, urease, arginine dihydrolase, ornithine decarboxylase and pyrrolidonyl arylamidase negative. Susceptible to furazolidon (100 μg) and resistant to novobiocin (5 μg) and bacitracin (10 IU). Hydrolysis of esculin, DNA and Tween 80 negative. Acid phosphatase (weak), esterase (C4), esterase lipase (C8), chymotrypsin and naphthol-AS-Bi-phosphohydrolase positive. Lipase (C14), alkaline phosphatase, leucine arylamidase, valine arylamidase, cystine arylamidase, trypsin, α-galactosidase, β-galactosidase, β-glucuronidase, α-glucosidase β-glucosidase, N-acetyl-β-glucosaminidase, α-mannosidase and α-fucosidase negative. Acid is produced from glycerol (weak), galactose, D-glucose, D-fructose, N-acetyl glucosamine, arbutin, salicin, maltose, lactose, sucrose, trehalose, D-raffinose (weak), β-gentiobiose and D-turanose (weak). Acid is not produced from erythritol, D-arabinose, L-arabinose, ribose, D-xylose, L-xylose, adonitol, β-methyl-D-xyloside, mannose, sorbose, rhamnose, dulcitol, inositol, mannitol, sorbitol, α-methyl-D-mannoside, α-methyl-D-glucoside, amygdaline, cellobiose, melibiose, inulin, melezitose, starch, glycogen, xylitol, D-lyxose, D-tagatose, D-fucose, L-fucose, D-arabitol, L-arabitol, gluconate, 2 keto-gluconate and 5 keto-gluconate. Susceptible to ampicillin, cefoxitin, cephalothin, ciprofloxacin, erythromycin, gentamicin, chloramphenicol, imipenem, kanamycin, neomycin, oxacillin, penicillin G, sulphamethox/trimethoprim (cotrimoxazol), tetracycline and vancomycin. Resistant to clindamycin. The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 34.9 mol% (calculated from WGS). Peptidoglycan type is A3α L-Lys-Gly1−2. Major fatty acids are C15:0 anteiso, C16:0 and C18:1 ω9c. Quinone system contains major component menaquinone MK-6 and minor components MK-5 and MK-7.The type strain is CCM 7100T (= DSM 103680T). Isolated from human clinical material (wound, knee). Sequence accession no. of 16S rRNA gene for the type strain is MH044692.10.3389/fmicb.2018.01178
DMBP00006784	Macrococcus epidermidis sp. nov. (e.pi.der'mi.dis. N.L. n. epidermis, outer skin (from Gr. pref. epi and Gr. n. derma, skin; Gr. n. epidermis, -idos, the outer skin); N.L. gen. n. epidermidis, of the outer skin).Cells are Gram-stain positive spherical cocci, occurring predominantly in pairs and clusters, non-spore forming and non-motile. Colonies on TSA agar are circular, with whole margins, convex with condensed centers, lustreless, 1–2 mm in diameter, aerobic and non-pigmented. No Haemolytic activity. Grows in the presence of up to 7.5% NaCl (weak), at 10 and 42°C but not at 5 or 45°C. No growth in the presence of 10% or more NaCl. Weak growth in thioglycolate medium. Catalase, oxidase, nitrate reduction, Voges-Proskauer test (acetoin) and hydrolysis of gelatin positive. Coagulase, clumping factor, urease, arginine dihydrolase, ornithine decarboxylase and pyrrolidonyl arylamidase negative. Susceptible to furazolidon (100 μg) and resistant to novobiocin (5 μg) and bacitracin (10 IU). Hydrolysis of esculin, DNA and Tween 80 negative. Acid phosphatase, alkaline phosphatase, esterase (C4), esterase lipase (C8) (weak), α-glucosidase (weak) and naphthol-AS-Bi-phosphohydrolase positive. Acid is produced from glycerol (weak), galactose, D-glucose, D-fructose, N-acetyl glucosamine, arbutin, salicin, maltose, lactose, sucrose, trehalose, melezitose, β-gentiobiose and D-turanose. Acid is not produced from erythritol, D-arabinose, L-arabinose, ribose, D-xylose, L-xylose, adonitol, β-methyl-D-xyloside, mannose, sorbose, rhamnose, dulcitol, inositol, mannitol, sorbitol, α-methyl-D-mannoside, α-methyl-D-glucoside, amygdaline, cellobiose, melibiose, inulin, D-raffinose, starch, glycogen, xylitol, D-lyxose, D-tagatose, D-fucose, L-fucose, D-arabitol, L-arabitol, gluconate, 2 keto-gluconate and 5 keto-gluconate. Resistant to clindamycin. The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 33.97 mol% (calculated from WGS). The peptidoglycan type is A3α Lys-Gly3-Ser. Isolated from human clinical material (swab, mycosis). Sequence accession no. of 16S rRNA gene for the type strain is MH044691.

(goe'tzi.i N.L. masc. gen. n. goetzii, of Goetz, named in honor of Prof. Dr. Friedrich Götz, a German microbiologist, for his contribution to the microbiology, physiology, and molecular biology of staphylococci and macrococci).Cells are Gram-stain positive irregular spherical cocci, occurring predominantly singly and in clusters, non-spore forming and non-motile. DMBP00006838	Pseudonocardia antarctica (ant.arc’ti.ca, N. L. adj. pertaining to the continent Antarctica) Aerobic, Gram-positive, non-motile and filamentous and produce brown colour substrate mycelia and aerial mycelia which form a white conglomerate. It produces spores by fragmentation of aerial mycelia. It exhibits optimum growth at 25 °C and grows between 7 to 38 °C, pH 4 to 10 and tolerates up to 8% NaCl. The strain is positive for catalase, oxidase, β-galactosidase, phosphatase, urease and gelatinase but negative for arginine dihydrolase, lipase, lysine and arginine decarboxylase. Hydrolyses aesculin and starch. Decomposes hypoxanthine and tyrosine but not xanthine. Reduces nitrate to nitrite. Negative for production of indole, methyl red test and Voges-Proskauer test. Produces acid from D-galactose, inulin, D-maltose, D-mannitol, D-mannose, L-rhamnose, D-ribose, D-xylose and D-raffinose but not from adonitol, D-arabinose, Dcellobiose, D-fructose, meso-inositol, melizitose, sorbitol, sucrose, D-trehalose, and xylitol. Utilizes adonitol, D-arabinose, D-cellobiose, D-galactose, D-glucose, glycerol, meso-inositol, inulin, lactose, lactic acid, D-maltose, Dmannose, D-mannitol, D-mellibiose, melizitose, D-raffinose, L-rhamnose, sorbose, D-trehalose, D-xylose, L-ala nine, L-arginine, L-aspargine, L-Histidine, L-proline, Ltryptophan and L-valine but not D-ribose, L-aspartic acid, succininc acid, L-isoleucine, L-leucine and L-phenylalanine as the sole source of carbon. Sensitive to amikacin, ampicillin, cefazoline, cefoperazone, cefuroxime, cephotaxime, ciprofloxacin, erythromycin, lomefloxacin, nitrofurantoin, penicillin, roxithromycin, streptomycin, tetracycline, tobramycin and vancomycin but resistant to co-trimoxazole, nalidixic acid, and norfloxacin. Meso-diaminopimelic acid, arabinose and galactose are present associated with the cell wall of the strain and MK-8 (H4) is the major menaquinone. The major phospholipids present are phosphotidylcholine, phosphotidylinositol, phosphotidyglycerol, diphosphotidyglycerol, phosphatidylethanolamine and phosphatidylmethylethanolamine. The fatty acid composition of the isolate is given in Table 2. The mol% G+C content of the DNA is 71%. The type strain is DVS 5a1T (MTCC 4297; DSM 44749). The EMBL accession number for the 16S rRNA gene sequence of Pseudonocardia antarctica (DVS 5a1T) is AJ576010.
DMBP00006893	DESCRIPTIONSKalamiella (N.L. fem. dim. n. Kalamiella, named after APJ Abdul Kalam (1934-2015), a well-known scientist who advanced space research in India)Cells are Gram-strain-negative, aerobic, motile short rods, occurring in the single or dual arrangement. Colonies are circular, convex with a diameter of approximately 0.6–1.0 mm and beige in color after 24 h of incubation on TSA medium at 30°C. Cell growth occurs at 12 to 37°C. The pH tolerance is between 6.0 and 10.0. and shows positive growth at 0 – 5% NaCl. Major cellular fatty acids (>10%) are C16:0, C17:0 cyclo, Summed Feature 3 and Summed Feature 8. The DNA G+C content is 57.07 mol%. Type species is Kalamiella piersonii.Kalamiella piersonii (pierson.i.i N.L gen. n. piersonii referring to Duane Pierson, an accomplished American space microbiologist.)Has the following characteristics in addition to those given for the genus. Cells are Gram-strain-negative, aerobic, motile short rods (1-1.2 x 2.8 um), occurring in the single or dual arrangement. Colonies are circular, convex with a diameter of approximately 0.6–1.0 mm and beige in color after 24 h of incubation on TSA medium at 30°C. Cell growth occurs at 12 and 37°C but not at 4 or 44°C. The optimum growth was observed at 30°C. The pH tolerance is between 6.0 and 10.0, with a pH optimum at 8.0. All of the strains displayed positive growth at 0 – 5% NaCl. The strains were positive for carbon source utilization of Dextrin, D-Maltose, N-Acetyl-D-Glucosamine, N-Acetyl-β-D-Mannosamine, α-D-Glucose, D-Mannose, D-Fructose, D-Galactose, L-Rhamnose, Inosine, 1% Sodium Lactate, D-Mannitol, myo-Inositol, Glycerol, D-Glucose-6-PO4, D-Fructose-6-PO4, Troleandomycin, Rifamycin SV, Glycyl- L-Proline, L-Alanine, L-Arginine, L-Aspartic Acid, L-Glutamic Acid, L-Histidine, Lincomycin, Guanidine HCl, Niaproof 4, D-Galacturonic Acid, L-Galactonic Acid Lactone, D-Gluconic Acid, D-Glucuronic Acid, Glucuronamide, Mucic Acid, D-Saccharic Acid, Vancomycin, Tetrazolium Violet, Tetrazolium Blue, Citric Acid, D-Malic Acid, L-Malic Acid, Lithium Chloride, and γ-Amino-Butyric Acid. The strains were negative for carbon source utilization of D-Trehalose, D-Cellobiose, Gentiobiose, Sucrose, D-Turanose, Stachyose, D-Raffinose, a-D-Lactose, D-Melibiose, b-Methyl-D-Glucoside, D-Salicin, N-Acetyl-D-Galactosamine, N-Acetyl Neuraminic Acid, 3-Methyl Glucose, D-Fucose, L-Fucose, Fusidic Acid, D-Serine, D-Sorbitol, D-Arabitol, D-Aspartic Acid, D-Serine, Minocycline, Gelatin, L-Pyroglutamic Acid, L-Serine, Pectin, Quinic Acid, p-Hydroxy-Phenylacetic Acid, Methyl Pyruvate, D-Lactic Acid Methyl Ester, L-Lactic Acid, α-Keto-Glutaric Acid, Bromo-Succinic Acid, Nalidixic Acid, Potassium Tellurite, Tween 40, α-Hydroxy-Butyric Acid, β-Hydroxy-D,L-Butyric Acid, α-Keto-Butyric Acid, Acetoacetic Acid, Propionic Acid, Acetic Acid, Formic Acid, Aztreonam, Sodium Butyrate, and Sodium Bromate. Major cellular fatty acids (>10%) are C16:0, C17:0 cyclo, Summed Feature 3 and Summed Feature 8. Lesser fatty acids are C12:0, C14:0, C14:0 2-OH, C19:0 cyclo ω8c, and Summed Feature 2.The type strain, IIIF1SW-P2T (=DSM 108198 =NRRL B-65522T), was isolated from the ISS Port panel of the Cupola, which is the observation deck for the crew. The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 57.07 mol% (whole genome).
DMBP00006916	162 Chitinophaga jiangningensis (jiang.ning.en'sis. N.L. fem. adj. jiangningensis referring to163 Jiangning district, Nanjing, Jiangsu Province, PR China, where the organism was first isolated).164 On R2A agar, colonies are yellow, circular, sticky and slightly convex. The strain can grow at pH 5.0-10.0, with an167 optimum of pH 7.0 and NaCl concentration range for growth is 0-6%. The strain can weather168 K-bearing rocks and release Si, Al, K, and Fe from K-bearing rocks.
